items.synopsis: In 1994, a looter codenamed The Falcon dug up an ancient treasure that decades later would end up in an Australian gallery. Now, it's being given back.

title.children: He dug up an ancient treasure. He had no idea the eye-watering price it would later fetch

image.altText: a close up of a curved dagger, known as a Kirpan, hanging from the belt of a robe

items.synopsis: The court ruling overturns an earlier decision that dismissed a claim from an Australian Sikh woman arguing the ban essentially prevented Sikhs from entering school grounds, which is against the Racial Discrimination Act.

title.children: A Queensland court just allowed some people to carry knives in schools. Here's why

image.altText: A young white woman carefully lifting a toddler up at a playground

items.synopsis: New research suggests the number of Australian women who sustain life-altering injuries to their pelvic floor after birth is far higher than acknowledged.

title.children: Pelvic floor physio before and after childbirth could reduce Australia's 'hidden epidemic'

image.altText: Three women sit on a reformer pilates bed holding their babies

items.synopsis: The pelvic floor is something most people don't talk about and many don't even know about. Here's why it's important and how to look after yours.

title.children: We rarely talk about pelvic floors. Here's why it's important and how to look after yours

image.altText: An Uber driver navigating using a mobile phone

items.synopsis: A record number of Australians are working multiple jobs, as employees try to keep up with a near 10 per cent surge in the cost of living.

title.children: Shaheryar has a professional job, but he's driving rideshare to make his mortgage — and he's not alone

image.altText: a man with his arms folded looks at the camera while standing in his kitchen

items.synopsis: Tristan Hockings claims his hearing problems "significantly deteriorated" after the alleged assault in January 2019, forcing him to leave his job as a nurse.

title.children: Tristan went on a date that ended in a police raid. Now he's suing police for alleged assault

image.altText: Three women and survivors of sexual abuse stand on a flight of stairs leading to the Maroochydore District Court.

items.synopsis: Four survivors of sexual abuse have told their story about a Sunshine Coast man who sexually assaulted them as children and how it severely impacted every aspect of their lives.

title.children: Decades after their abuse ended, four women unite to jail a paedophile

image.altText: Blue ocean lapping up against white sand and a grassy hill with tall palm trees.

items.synopsis: A global minimum tax is designed to stop multinationals avoiding taxes. But some experts argue it may have unintended consequences.

title.children: Corporate tax avoidance costs trillions a year. But Australia's plan to end it could create new problems

image.altText: Girl standing with her back to the camera, wearing a backpack.

items.synopsis: Universities are failing to meet a key recommendation set out by the Australian Human Rights Commission to support students who are victims of sexual violence, as pressure grows on the federal government to hold the sector accountable.

title.children: 'They leave our cries unheard': Universities accused of failing sexual assault victims

image.altText: Anthony Albanese pointing in question time.

items.synopsis: From voice to truth to treaty and Makarrata, there are a lot of words being thrown around in the Voice to Parliament debate coming from Canberra. So, what have they got to do with the upcoming referendum?

title.children: Is there treaty in the Voice? What is treaty and truth-telling? Voice to Parliament questions answered

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: The Australian stock market is set to fall after a big slump on US indices.

title.children: Wall St falls after ratings cut, ASX to follow

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The flagship ASX 200 index of the largest 200 listed companies in Australia has opened down at the start of trading. At 10:04AM it was -0.21%, off -21.2 points to 7,333.4 This wasn't unexpected given the weak lead from the US, where the key indices fell after a grim view of future conditions was triggered by a ratings agency downgrading the prospects of the nation's economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 opens down after Wall Street's slump

children.content: The flagship ASX 200 index of the largest 200 listed companies in Australia has opened down at the start of trading.
At 10:04AM it was -0.21%, off -21.2 points to 7,333.4

This wasn't unexpected given the weak lead from the US, where the key indices fell after a grim view of future conditions was triggered by a ratings agency downgrading the prospects of the nation's economy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Morning! Big drops on US indicies have paved the way for what could be some solid loses on the Australian stockmarket. The Dow Jones was down -0.1%, the broader S & P 500 off -1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq a big -2.2% in trade. The US market was shocked by a credit downgrade from one of the key ratings agencies - meaning it thinks the country is a bit riskier for investors than it was yesterday. That can trigger higher interest payments but the biggest blow is probably to confidence in the market. The ASX futures market is at 7,241 points, down 58 points or -0.8%. But we'll see when our market opens at 10AM AEST. Anyway, lots more to come so settle in!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street slump sets stage for ASX falls

children.content: Big drops on US indicies have paved the way for what could be some solid loses on the Australian stockmarket.
The Dow Jones was down -0.1%, the broader S
P 500 off -1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq a big -2.2% in trade.
The US market was shocked by a credit downgrade from one of the key ratings agencies - meaning it thinks the country is a bit riskier for investors than it was yesterday.
That can trigger higher interest payments but the biggest blow is probably to confidence in the market.
The ASX futures market is at 7,241 points, down
58 points or -0.8%. But we'll see when our market opens at 10AM AEST.
Anyway, lots more to come so settle in!

image.altText: Sydney skyline at night.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest companies are detailing the impact cost-of-living pressures and high interest rates have had on their bottom line. Analysts say the results will give an early warning sign as to where the economy is heading.

title.children: 'Consumer spending has really fallen off a cliff': Corporate reporting season offers a window on the economy's future

image.altText: A woman crouched down next to a chicken outside a large shed.

items.synopsis: A Queensland researcher has developed a camera-based system that can analyse the behaviour of chickens when they think there are no humans watching and determine how happy they are.

title.children: Algorithm to bring big brother to the chicken sheds in effort to improve welfare

image.altText: Panama's Marta Cox slides on her knees to celebrate a goal at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Panama captain Marta Cox scores a stunning free kick against France, the World Cup career of a legend ends, and South Africa takes down football giants. Here are five quick hits from Wednesday's matches.

title.children: World Cup five quick hits — Brazil great Marta bows out as another Marta scores possible goal of the tournament

image.altText: AI companies have been accused of unlawfully using copyrighted content

items.synopsis: The media and arts union tell the government AI owners should pay compensation for the content used to train their tools, while big tech asks for exemptions from copyright laws.

title.children: Fight brews on AI copyright law, as unions say big tech must pay to train AI, while Google, Microsoft ask for exemptions

image.altText: Karen Kennedy and her son Aaron Kennedy

items.synopsis: A clinic with ties to a cult that teaches that disability is "karma" has received thousands of dollars under the NDIS scheme.

title.children: Aaron's carer, who was funded by NDIS, was part of a 'cult' that teaches that disabilities are 'karma'

image.altText: A knight in armour on horseback

items.synopsis: Sir Darrell Bosley, as he is known, took up jousting at 66. When people ask him why he took it up at that age, he replies "because it's easier than starting at 67".

title.children: Meet Darrell, a modern-day medieval knight. At 77, he's the world's oldest jouster

image.altText: Investigators examine a damaged skyscraper in Moscow.

items.synopsis: The IQ Complex in Moscow's west has been the target of successive drone strikes in what Russia has called an attempted "terrorist attack".

title.children: Why has this skyscraper in Moscow been hit by two drone strikes in three days?

image.altText: A 'sold' property sign in the window of a building

items.synopsis: The report analyses consumer behaviour by extracting property market data from 12.1 million Australians.

title.children: Property market strength set to continue, according to new report

image.altText: Beaded star of david in pink green and blue hangs on pole outside building

items.synopsis: The 2018 Pittsburgh shooting was one of the deadliest anti-Semitic attacks in US history.

title.children: Gunman who killed 11 in synagogue shooting to be sentenced to death

image.altText: A large piece of machinery being pulled from the water.

items.synopsis: Inside the army community there is growing anger over Friday's tragedy and speculation the troubled MRH-90 fleet may never return to full operations.

title.children: 'Furious': Anger inside army at fatal Taipan helicopter crash

image.altText: middle aged man in handle bar moustache smiles at camera

items.synopsis: A New South Wales coroner has noted "a number of inconsistencies" in the accounts of the nurse on duty and doctor on call at the Junee Correctional Centre on the morning an inmate and father of three complained of chest pains

title.children: Inquest into loving father's jail death reveals 'Inconsistencies'

image.altText: A woman wearing a red jacket with brown hair closes her eyes and sings with a team-mate next to her

items.synopsis: Christine Sinclair was quietly subbed off at half-time against the Matildas, drawing to a close a monumental World Cup career in a fittingly understated fashion.

title.children: With Canada's World Cup elimination, football's greatest striker takes a quiet bow

image.altText: Paul McCartney raises his arms on stage

items.synopsis: Whenever Paul McCartney picks up the guitar to compose new music he still wonders what John Lennon would make of it.

title.children: 'I'm singing with my old buddy again': Paul McCartney on how AI is bringing John Lennon back on stage

image.altText: Angela Fitzwater sits in a chair in a home, dressed warmly as she looks forward with a serious expression.

items.synopsis: After falling victim to scams, the 83-year-old spent three months chasing an answer from her bank's fraud department.

title.children: Angela realised the 'hi mum' scam too late — but feels her bank let her down with what came next

image.altText: An older man in a suit sit next to a robot as they wait for a job interview

items.synopsis: Artificial Intelligence is coming, the employment landscape will be disrupted and the best strategy is to try to keep up — that was the key message at a major business conference.

title.children: Jobs will be 'transformed' and potentially 'destroyed': Businesses told to embrace AI or get left behind

image.altText: Cruise ship passengers disembark from the Princess Cruises owned Ruby Princess at Circular Quay in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A number of passengers of the COVID-affected Ruby Princess had signed a contract waiving rights to join class actions. The customers say that contract breached Australian consumer law.

title.children: Some Ruby Princess passengers signed a contract waiving rights to class actions. They're taking the fight to the High Court

image.altText: A headshot of Belinda

items.synopsis: Professional garbologist Bel has so little landfill waste she's ditched her red bin. Here's how she did it.

title.children: Bel has reduced her household waste to just 4kg a year. This is how she ditched her red bin

image.altText: A cow stands in a her wearing a small device on a collar

items.synopsis: Each morning when Tasmanian farmer Duncan Macdonald wakes up and heads to the milking shed, his herd of dairy cows is already there and waiting — thanks to "virtual fencing" technology.

title.children: 'We turn up and the cows are there, ready to be milked': The new tech giving farmers a sleep-in

image.altText: A drawing of a marine mammal built somewhat like a manatee under the ocean

items.synopsis: Italian researchers estimate Perucetus, or "colossal Peruvian whale", was about 20 metres long and weighed up to 340 tonnes, a mass greater than the blue whale and the largest dinosaurs.

title.children: Could this 'colossal Peruvian whale' be the biggest animal ever on Earth?
